{{Taxobox | image = Catathelasma imperiale 107604.jpg | image_width = 240px | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Tricholomataceae]] | genus = ''[[Catathelasma]]'' | species = '''''C. imperiale''''' | binomial = ''Catathelasma imperiale'' | binomial_authority = ([[Lucien Quélet|Quél.]]) [[Rolf Singer|Singer]] | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = 1845 ''Agaricus imperialis'' [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]
1872 ''Armillaria imperialis'' Quél.
1886 ''Omphalia imperialis'' (Quél.) Quél.
1914 ''Armillaria nobilis'' [[William Alphonso Murrill|Murrill]]
1914 ''Clitocybe imperialis'' (Quél.) [[Aldabert Ricken|Ricken]]
1922 ''Biannularia imperialis'' (Quél.) [[Günther Beck von Mannagetta und Lerchenau|Beck]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Catathelasma imperiale'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = convex | capShape2 = depressed | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = ring | ecologicalType = mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor = white | howEdible = edible }} '''''Catathelasma imperiale''''' is a large [[species]] of mushroom in the [[Tricholomataceae]] family. It is found in North America and Europe. ==Description== The following description combines several references. *'''Cap''': 8 – 40 cm, orange brown to hazel brown, with darker patches. Often remaining closed up with a domed shape, but sometimes expanding and finally depressed. *'''Gills''': Whitish, decurrent, crowded, sometimes forked. *'''Stem''': Pale brown with two rings. Tapering below, often partly buried. *'''Odor''': Of flour, cucumber or unripe melon skin. *'''Spores''': White (en masse), 10 - 15 x 5 - 6 [[μm]], smooth, somewhat spindle-shaped, [[Amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]]. *'''Habitat''': Under conifers, especially [[Pine]] and [[Spruce]], in mountainous regions. European sources give the cap size as up to about 20 cm, while North American ones indicate an enormous maximum size of 40 cm. The upper ring is derived from the [[partial veil]] (which covered the lower surface of the cap before it opened), whereas the thinner lower ring originally formed part of the [[universal veil]] (which enveloped the whole mushroom). ==Taxonomy and Related Species== ''C. imperiale'' is the only species of ''Catathelasma'' known in Europe. It was first described in 1845 by [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fries]] under the name ''Agaricus imperialis''. In 1872 [[Quélet]] classified the species in ''[[Armillaria]]'' and in 1922 the Austrian botanist [[Günther Beck von Mannagetta und Lerchenau]] invented the separate genus ''Biannularia'' for this single species, making it ''Biannularia imperialis''. The genus ''Catathelasma'' had been defined in 1910 by Ruth Ellen Harrison Lovejoy based on the American species ''[[Catathelasma evanescens|C. evanescens]]'' and for a time the two genera were regarded as separate (though closely related), as for instance in a 1936 paper by [[Rolf Singer]]. A few years later in 1940, Singer united the genus using Lovejoy's name, which takes precedence. The epithet "''imperiale''", meaning "imperial" refers to the (at times) large size of the mushroom. The species name must end in "-e", not "-is", as the genus is neuter. ==General== In Europe this species has something of an iconic status amongst mycologists as an impressive and remarkable mushroom to find. It occurs in western North America and in various European countries (mainly in central Europe) where its frequency varies from "fairly rare" to "rare". ''C. imperiale'' is edible, but tough-fleshed. It is said to be good pickled. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite book |author=Marcel Bon |title=The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North-Western Europe |publisher=Hodder & Stoughton |year=1987 |page=162 |isbn=0-340-39935-X }} {{cite book |author1=Courtecuisse, R. |author2=Duhem, B. |title=Guide des champignons de France et d'Europe |publisher=Delachaux et Niestlé |year=1994 |page=208 |isbn=2-603-00953-2}} Also available in English. {{cite book |authorlink=Henning Knudsen |editor2-link=Jan Vesterhout |title=Funga Nordica |publisher=Nordsvamp |location=Copenhagen |year=2008 |pages=429}} See the [http://healing-mushrooms.net/archives/catathelasma-imperiale.html healing-mushrooms.net entry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427065546/http://healing-mushrooms.net/archives/catathelasma-imperiale.html |date=2012-04-27 }}. The [http://www.speciesfungorum.org/Names/SynSpecies.asp?RecordID=284817 Species Fungorum page] shows the full naming history. {{cite book |author=[[Robert Kühner]] & [[Henri Romagnesi]] |title=Flore analytique des champignons supérieurs (agarics, bolets, chanterelles) |publisher=Masson |location=Paris |year=1974 |language=French |page=143|isbn=2-225-53713-5}} The mushroom appears here under the name ''Biannularia''. Kuo, M. (2006, October). ''Catathelasma imperiale''. See [http://www.mushroomexpert.com/catathelasma_imperiale.html the MushroomExpert.Com Web site]. {{cite journal |title=Some New Saprophytic Fungi of the Middle Rocky Mountain Region |journal=The Botanical Gazette |author=Ruth Harrison Lovejoy |year=1910 |volume=50 |page=383}} The text can be found on-line in [https://archive.org/stream/mobot31753002217245/mobot31753002217245_djvu.txt The Internet Archive].
